Another snapshot a few hours' drive from the Buddhist temple - in a dimly lit crypt, a man named Wahjudi Djaja performs a ritual unique to his brand of Islam.
Wahjudi is quietly saying the prayer under his breath as he sits cross-legged in front of the tomb.
He sprinkles flowers on the grave.
This is a local form of Islam called Kejawen.
The rituals involve amulets and a Goddess known as the Queen of the South Sea.
Over lunch, Djaja tells me that he fears Indonesia is becoming more intolerant.
